Key Arguments: The Bill does not acknowledge how communications made in good faith and based on deeply held beliefs contribute to the common good.
There is concern that the Bill could be used to portray the Church's communication of its teachings as public misinformation.
The Bill should safeguard the communication of sincerely held religious beliefs as an important contribution to the common good.
Religious communications made in good faith should be exempt from the Bill's scope, similar to content produced for entertainment, parody, or satire.
Main Themes: Concerns about censorship of religious content
Comparison with exemptions for entertainment and satire
Notable Quotes: The proposed Bill does not acknowledge how communications made in good faith and on the basis of deeply held beliefs contribute to the common good.
The legislation should provide that communications of religious belief made in good faith...should not be included in the scope of the Bill.
It would be perverse if content produced in good faith for satire was allowed, while content that talks about our deepest beliefs was not.
